title: I am the First Successor Trustee in my father's Revokable Trust. The Trust might be in debt. How do I remove myself ?
question: My father has a Trust and is a Trustee. I am nominated first Successor Trustee in the event of my father's incapacity or death.
answers:
Under general principles of law, I do not see how a successor trustee could be liable for indebtedness of a trust which preceded his tenure as trustee. I know of no provision of law that makes a successor trustee a guarantor liable for a trust's prior debts. It just doesn't make sense.

However, if you signed something when your father was admitted to the rehabilitation facility which made you responsible for the bill, that may be the source of legal liability on which the rehabilitation facility could proceed against you if the trust is unable to pay the bills of your father.

With respect to the question of whether you could be "chased," debt collection companies will sometimes pursue relatives of a deceased debtor. These companies have learned that relatives sometimes pay obligations incurred by the deceased debtor even though they have no legal obligation to do so. See New York Times article linked below.

Not legal advice as I don't practice law in California. It's just my two cents on the facts you describe in light of general principles of law. If you need legal advice, please consult a lawyer who holds California licensure.

Good luck.
As others have noted, you cannot be held personally liable for your father's debts unless you personally guaranteed them or cosigned for them.

Your question is confusing on a few different fronts but that may be because you do not have all the facts. You as a Trustee will not have personal liability for the debts of the Trust. You as a beneficiary will only have liability to the extent of any assets you receive, that are perhaps disbursed prior to creditors claims being paid. He is alive but incapacitated so you are next in line for the throne so to speak. I don't know what your father's ex-wife is doing selling his house or under what authority she is acting but perhaps she is helping him unload a property that owes more than it is worth. If that is so, and you are sure there is nothing else in the Trust, there is nothing in the Trust over which to be Trustee perhaps. You will not know from there in the UK. He may have bank accounts and assets in the home or apartment where he lived prior to going to the rehab facility. Did the ex move him out of the home to sell it and into the facility? Where are his belongings? There is so much you don't know but you can know that you are not personally liable for your Father's debts. Not in America.
